posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked:
How has your team made good looking sponsor boards in the past? I’m particularly interested in how teams make sponsor boards like 254’s:

but others methods and creative sponsor boards would be interesting to me as well (1678’s bellypan sponsorboard in 2023 comes to mind).

I’m interested in all the details:

Was it done in house (and if so what machines) or did you pay/get sponsored to have someone else make it (if so who?)

Material details inc. thickness, vendor, etc. (if relevant)

What was the cost in terms of time and $$?

Are there methods you’d recommend for particular budgets/capabilities/time investment?

posts.name: Charlie Peskay
posts.cooked:
We buy black polycarbonate and use custom vinyl stickers made with a cricut. Looks good and is fairly simple. IMG_5749 2421×1973 1.36 MB IMG_5816 3024×4032 2.86 MB

IMG_5749 2421×1973 1.36 MB

IMG_5749 2421×1973 1.36 MB

IMG_5816 3024×4032 2.86 MB

IMG_5816 3024×4032 2.86 MB

posts.name: Matthew K
posts.cooked: We also cut our vinyl stickers with a cricut, but instead of making purpose built sponsor panels, we usually just put them somewhere on one of our mechanisms that has a polycarb piece to it

posts.name: ben gates
posts.cooked:
In 2023 3357 first tried using custom-printed transparent vinyl sheets after getting sick of cutting out cricut vinyl by hand for tiny logos. Logos were sharp and it was way easier but did lack the vibrancy of the cricut vinyl. (2022 with cricut vs. 2023 with transparent vinyl):

IMG_8629 1920×2560 709 KB

IMG_8629 1920×2560 709 KB

IMG_8629 1920×2560 709 KB

12 reveal thumbnail 1920×1080 198 KB

12 reveal thumbnail 1920×1080 198 KB

12 reveal thumbnail 1920×1080 198 KB

both were just mounted on smoked polycarb (basically as an afterthought). totally depends on robot design, but you can usually fit a polycarb panel to almost anything with decent mounting, especially if you’re able to do bends in polycarb. in 2023 we had to make our panels easily removable for quick access, so the sides were just two bolts a piece and the back had two 3D-printed ziptie blocks that made it only a slight nuisance to pop off. I would recommend against needing to remove panels for access if possible, but there are protective benefits if you do, and bolts, zipties, and velcro all work well for quick release

posts.name: Isaac Proctor
posts.cooked: In recent years, 6343 has used clear, 1/4" polycarbonate with stickers of our sponsors’ logos. Most of the time, these polycarb plates have served some function on the robot(last year we put it over the bellypan to stop notes from getting stuck). We machine them ourselves with our CNC engraver, and we don’t do it until close to competition, so the rest of our robot is built first and so it hopefully doesn’t get in the way of future design changes.

posts.name: Erik Boyle
posts.cooked:
Vinyl cut decals are the way to go. We get ours from a local shop, but with someone handy with a Cricut could do it as well.

My one recommendation is to always use or ask your vendor for transfer tape for your decals, even if you’re just using blocky shapes. It is so much easier to line them up and keep everything square when you can hold the tape rather than hanging the cutouts off the tips of your fingers while you stick them on your panels. And if you have access to a large enough cutter, you can even design whole layouts of multiple logos and transfer them all at once with the exact spacing that you want.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Somewhere between Thunderstruck and Country Roads

posts.custom_user_title: Somewhere between Thunderstruck and Country Roads

posts.name: Travis Covington
posts.cooked:
Max_Morehead:

Was it done in house (and if so what machines) or did you pay/get sponsored to have someone else make it (if so who?)

Material details inc. thickness, vendor, etc. (if relevant)

What was the cost in terms of time and $$?

Are there methods you’d recommend for particular budgets/capabilities/time investment?

We handle this in-house using a laser cutter, sheet metal shears, and a vinyl cutter. The material choice depends on the application—tinted polycarbonate in various thicknesses is used based on whether the panel is structural or purely cosmetic. For non-structural panels or applications requiring less rigidity, WCP offers .030 tinted polycarbonate, which works perfectly.

While the design process can take a few hours, cutting the polycarbonate, applying vinyl, and finishing the panels is relatively quick—usually just a few hours. We typically complete this right before taking the robot photos, sometimes immediately beforehand.

The costs are minimal. A good vinyl cutter for smaller graphics can be found for under $100. We use a larger model that handles up to 30–36" wide vinyl rolls, making it easier to create larger designs in a single pass.

This process is straightforward, and I highly recommend it to teams with members who are interested and willing to take ownership from start to finish. The biggest challenge is designing clean, professional-looking panels that adhere to sponsor branding guidelines. Many teams either overcrowd their designs or shrink logos too much, making them difficult to see or cut accurately. The most time should be spent refining the design. We even Photoshop the panel onto the robot CAD model before cutting, and you can also import the design file into CAD for a preview of the final look.

posts.name: Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)
posts.cooked:
We send our panels out to Office Depot. It’s cheap to get something that looks great;the whole panel for Iceberg was around $20. The secret is good vector art, a style that’s as subtle as a brick to the head (okay I guess that’s optional), and a good understanding of the clearances required.

IMG_0187 3024×4032 3.05 MB IMG_2467 3024×4032 2.64 MB IMG_3588 3024×4032 2.38 MB

posts.name: AllenGregoryIV
posts.cooked:
We CAD our sponsor panels, export the DXF into an image program and then arrange the sponsor graphics. Print the graphics on paper (we have a 24" wide printer) with a faint outline of the panel. Cut out the panel outline. Then laminate the cut outs. We then cut the panels out of clear polycarb (0.03 to 1/16"). Then tape the laminated prints to the back of the clear panels with packing tape.

Scratches on the polycarb never hit the prints and it’s easy enough to replace or swap prints or polycarb if needed.

posts.name: Dkt01
posts.cooked:
We also use cut adhesive vinyl on clear polycarb.  In the past, we’ve used various vinyl cutters with varying success.  One of our teachers has a Cricut which does really well with small details, so that’s what we use now.

We cut the logos mirrored so they can be adhered to the inside of the clear polycarb.  Then we mask off edges and spray paint the back black.  Finally, we usually cover the paint with gaffers tape so we don’t accidentally scratch it when handling the panels.

If you do this, be sure to get a spray paint that’s good for plastic.  One we used in 2018 made the polycarbonate panels brittle.

IMG_2057 1920×2560 720 KB

IMG_2057 1920×2560 720 KB

IMG_2057 1920×2560 720 KB

posts.name: Elliot S
posts.cooked:
We tend to use paper that are lamented and then cut to size, our one of our high schools has a print shop so they print them for us.

Also, note, if you are a little overboard with graphics(like us) that most companies have branding standards, which includes the color of the logo and the background color for spastic scenarios, this results in us using a white background for our sponsor panels. A lot of sponsors probably worry too much for on robot decals but it is something to consider.

Here is an image from our branding standards booklet about it: image 1267×1606 466 KB Link to full booklet: https://ligerbots.org/docs/2022/LigerBots_Branding_Standards_2022.pdf
